description.narrative: Distribution of 1,000 shelter kits + 2,000 tarps, 1,000 hygiene kits and 1,000 kitchen kits

Phalombe and Mulanje districts are affected by floods almost each and every year. The frequency of floods has been increasing over the years, resulting in loss of life, damage to property and destruction of the environment. According to ACAPS publication, as of 18th March 2019, over 125,382 people had been displaced since the onset of flooding in Malawi caused by the forming of Cyclone Idai. This figure represents a significant increase since 10th March 2019, when 31,700 people were recorded as displaced as a result of the flooding. Many displaced people have had their homes and personal property damaged by the flooding and face elevated shelter needs as a result. In Phalombe district, approximately 5,500 houses have collapsed, and in Mulanje district 2000 houses have reportedly been collapsed. (Malawi News Agency 11/03/2019; The Nation 13/03/2019). Most of the displaced population are hosted in 187 camps that have been established in the affected districts while others are in makeshift sites in schools and churches where access to adequate shelter is often lacking (Reuters 13/03/2019).
The displaced people disrupted the school sessions since the class rooms are temporarily being used as the evacuation home and some are seeking shelter in community holes or churches. This is contributing to some sanitation issues on the school and church premises and remains a challenge in the temporary shelters at the camp site. Lack of proper toilets at the camp offers privacy and security concerns to women and girls. From these events, the Village Development committee (VDC) and the Community Based Organization through participatory vulnerability assessment, identified the need to have stronger houses that can withstand heavy rains.
